qas.question: The ARR was one of the last railroads in the US to use what?
When are cabooses still used occasionally?
When was the Parks Highway constructed?
The ARR wasn't one of the last railroads in the US to use what?
The ARR was one of the first railroads in the US to use what?
The ARR was one of the last railroads in the UN to use what?
When aren't cabooses still used occasionally?
When was the Parks Highway destroyed?

context: The Alaska Railroad was one of the last railroads in North America to use <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0><b5_0>cabooses<b5_0/><b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> in regular service and still uses them on <a1_0><b6_0>some gravel trains<b6_0/><a1_0/>. It continues to offer one of the last flag stop routes in the country. A stretch of about 60 miles (100 km) of track along an area north of Talkeetna remains inaccessible by road; the railroad provides the only transportation to rural homes and cabins in the area. Until construction of the Parks Highway in the <a2_0><b7_0>1970s<b7_0/><a2_0/>, the railroad provided the only land access to most of the region along its entire route.
